name: Jacob Collier
description: A highly acclaimed singer, songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, and producer, known for his intricate harmonies and genre-defying music. He gained early fame on YouTube with multi-instrumental covers and has won multiple Grammy Awards.

name: Anoushka Shankar
description: Sitar player and composer, daughter of Ravi Shankar. She is a prominent figure in Indian classical music and contemporary world music, known for crossing genres and styles.

name: Brian Jones
description: Founding member and original multi-instrumentalist of The Rolling Stones. Known for introducing a variety of unique instruments, including Indian and African sounds, to the band's early recordings.

name: Carolina Eyck
description: A renowned virtuoso theremin player, composer, and author. She developed a precise playing technique for the theremin and frequently performs with voice and orchestra.

name: Andy Narell
description: An internationally celebrated jazz steel pannist, composer, and music educator. He is a pioneer in bringing the steelpan into the jazz world and composing for steel orchestras.

name: Gabby La La (Gabby Lang)
description: A vocalist and multi-instrumentalist whose music is often described as quirky and experimental. She is classically trained on the sitar and has collaborated with artists like Les Claypool.

name: William Barton
description: Australia's leading didgeridoo (Yidaki) player, as well as a composer, instrumentalist, and vocalist. He is known for blending traditional Aboriginal music with Western classical orchestras and various ensembles.

name: George Harrison
description: Lead guitarist of The Beatles. He was instrumental in introducing Indian classical music and instruments like the sitar to popular Western music.

name: Ravi Shankar
description: An iconic Indian sitar virtuoso and composer. He is credited with introducing the sitar and Indian classical music to a wider Western audience.

name: Famoudou Konaté
description: A Malinké master drummer and a virtuoso of the djembe drum. He is dedicated to performing and preserving the traditional music of his people and was the lead djembe soloist for Les Ballets Africains.

name: Gordon Duncan
description: One of the greatest and most innovative exponents of the Great Highland Bagpipes, known for his blend of traditional and contemporary influences, including his famed arrangement of AC/DC's 'Thunderstruck'.

name: Naseer Shamma
description: A highly respected oud virtuoso, composer, and founder of The Arab Oud House. He has won numerous international awards and is known for his cross-cultural musical collaborations and humanitarian work.

name: Stella Chiweshe
description: A Zimbabwean musician internationally known as the 'Queen of Mbira' for her singing and mastery of the mbira dzavadzimu, a traditional instrument of the Shona people. She was a pioneering female mbira player.

name: Ravi Shankar
description: Legendary sitar virtuoso and composer who popularized Indian classical music globally, collaborated with George Harrison and performed at Woodstock

name: Anoushka Shankar
description: Renowned sitar player and composer, daughter of Ravi Shankar, known for innovative fusion of classical Indian music with modern influences

name: Vilayat Khan
description: Master sitar player known for creating the gayaki ang technique which mimics the human voice, released first recording at age six

name: Nikhil Banerjee
description: Child prodigy and master sitarist, revered as one of the greatest traditional sitarists of the 20th century

name: George Harrison
description: The Beatles lead guitarist and acclaimed solo artist who helped popularize the sitar in Western music

name: Brian Jones
description: Rolling Stones co-founder and multi-instrumentalist who played sitar on 'Paint It Black' and 'Street Fighting Man'

name: Emily Strayer
description: Original member of The Chicks, multi-instrumentalist proficient in banjo, sitar, accordion, and various stringed instruments

name: Mamady Keïta
description: Master djembe player, lead soloist of Djoliba National Ballet, founded Tam Tam Mandingue percussion school

name: Famoudou Konaté
description: Master of Malinké drumming, lead djembe soloist in Les Ballets Africains for 28 years

name: Babatunde Olatunji
description: World-renowned master drummer who introduced Americans to African drumming and spiritual depth of percussion

name: Ladji Camara
description: Legendary lead djembe drummer with Les Ballet Africains, credited with popularizing the instrument globally

name: Soungalo Coulibaly
description: Revered djembe player and composer known for intense energy and innovative rhythmic patterns

name: Bolokada Conde
description: Master djembe drummer and teacher, renowned for traditional Malinke beats

name: Leon Mobley
description: World renowned percussionist, member of Grammy-winning Ben Harper and the Innocent Criminals, founder of Djembe West African Drummers and Dancers

name: Eric Rigler
description: Described as 'the most recorded bagpiper of all time', plays multiple forms of bagpipes and featured on numerous movie soundtracks

name: Martyn Bennett
description: Influential musician in modern Celtic fusion, known as 'the techno piper', blended traditional Celtic and modern music

name: Gordon Duncan
description: Bagpiper and composer known for innovative approach to traditional Scottish music

name: Jori Chisholm
description: Professional bagpipe player with Simon Fraser University Pipe Band, four-time US Gold Medal winner

name: Rufus Harley
description: First jazz musician to adopt the Great Highland bagpipe as primary instrument, performed with John Coltrane and Dizzy Gillespie

name: Michio Miyagi
description: Blind composer and innovator who combined Western music with traditional koto, created 17-string bass koto

name: Kazue Sawai
description: Master koto player finding new places for the instrument in jazz, experimental and pop music

name: June Kuramoto
description: Member of jazz fusion group Hiroshima, one of the first to popularize koto in non-traditional fusion style

name: Curtis Patterson
description: First non-Japanese graduate of NHK master's program for traditional Japanese music performers, koto virtuoso based in Japan

name: Masayo Ishigure
description: Multi-faceted koto and jiuta shamisen player who stretches the limits of koto while maintaining tradition

name: Djalu Gurruwiwi
description: Yolngu elder and master yidaki player, important custodian of the didgeridoo, dedicated to preserving traditional practices

name: William Barton
description: Leading didgeridoo player known for innovative fusion with classical music, performed with major orchestras worldwide

name: David Hudson
description: Cultural Journeyman of Australia, co-founded Tjapukai dance troupe, blends didgeridoo with various musical styles

name: Mark Atkins
description: Storyteller, songwriter, composer and painter, worked with Robert Plant, Jimmy Page, and Philip Glass

name: Alan Dargin
description: First didgeridoo virtuoso who developed contemporary playing techniques, performed with Vienna Philharmonic and London Symphony

name: Charlie McMahon
description: Father of contemporary didgeridoo, founder of Gondwanaland Project, inventor of the didjeribone (sliding didgeridoo)

name: Xavier Rudd
description: Singer and multi-instrumentalist who frequently features didgeridoo in his performances

name: Munir Bashir
description: Master oud player who perfected the Arab Maqamat genre, one of the greatest Middle Eastern musicians of the 20th century

name: Riyad Al Sunbati
description: World-class composer, singer, and oud player who composed over 500 pieces for Egyptian cinema and opera

name: Farid al-Atrash
description: Virtuoso oud player, composer, singer, and actor with a prolific four-decade career

name: Naseer Shamma
description: World-renowned oud player and poet, founder of the Arabic Oud House in Cairo

name: Simon Shaheen
description: Contemporary master with impeccable technique, oud and violin virtuoso, Arabic music lecturer

name: Ara Dinkjian
description: World-renowned oud player and composer, founder of Night Ark, song 'Dinata Dinata' performed at 2004 Athens Olympics closing

name: Rahim Al Haj
description: World-class composer and oud player, student of Munir Bashir, known for impressive playing and political activism

name: Stella Chiweshe
description: Mbira queen and pioneer, one of the first women to play mbira publicly, used music for socio-political commentary

name: Hope Masike
description: Known as the 'princess of mbira', contemporary custodian creating bold urban fusion music with the mbira

name: Thomas Mapfumo
description: Known as Mukanya, 'Lion of Zimbabwe', fathered electric mbira music and developed chimurenga music style

name: Fradreck Mujuru
description: One of the greatest mbira players alive, master of multiple mbira tunings, renowned instrument maker

name: Erica Azim
description: Respected teacher and scholar of mbira, studied traditional Zimbabwean music extensively

name: Maurice White
description: Founder of Earth, Wind & Fire, helped popularize mbira in the 1960s-70s by incorporating it with modern rock instruments

name: Ellie Mannette
description: Father of the Modern Steel Drum, developed concave sinking technique, creator of double seconds pan

name: Winston 'Spree' Simon
description: Inventor of the ping pong pan (tenor pan), pioneered steelpan development, master tuner

name: Lennox 'Boogsie' Sharpe
description: Living legend with perfect pitch, dazzling virtuosity, arranger for Phase II Pan Groove with 7 Panorama wins

name: Jit Samaroo
description: Known as 'Dr. Jit', one of the most prolific arrangers, led Renegades to 9 Panorama victories

name: Sterling Betancourt
description: Pioneer and musician, original TASPO player who premiered steel pan at 1951 Festival of Britain

name: Othello Molineaux
description: First to use steelpan in jazz medium, worked with Jaco Pastorius, Monty Alexander, and Chicago

name: Leon Theremin
description: Inventor of the theremin, first to perform using the instrument, performed for Lenin and New York Philharmonic

name: Clara Rockmore
description: Violin prodigy turned theremin virtuoso, helped popularize the instrument in classical music

name: Carolina Eyck
description: Theremin revolutionist who developed her own technique, performed at Kennedy Center and Walt Disney Concert Hall

name: Dorit Chrysler
description: Composer, producer, singer, and theremin wizard, co-founder of New York Theremin Society

name: Pamelia Kurstin
description: Innovative theremin player with jazz background, pioneered walking bass lines on theremin

name: Lydia Kavina
description: Granddaughter of Léon Theremin's first cousin, master teacher and performer

name: Prince
description: Legendary multi-instrumentalist who played 27+ instruments on his debut album, mastered guitar, piano, bass, drums, and saxophone

name: Paul McCartney
description: The Beatles bassist and legendary multi-instrumentalist proficient with 54 musical instruments

name: Stevie Wonder
description: Legendary singer and multi-instrumentalist, virtuoso on keyboard instruments and harmonica

name: Jimi Hendrix
description: Revolutionary electric guitar virtuoso, considered one of the greatest guitarists of all time

name: Eric Clapton
description: Blues-rock guitar legend, known for work with Cream, Derek and the Dominos, and solo career

name: Yo-Yo Ma
description: World-renowned cellist, multiple Grammy Award winner, known for classical and cross-cultural collaborations

name: Itzhak Perlman
description: Violin virtuoso and conductor, one of the world's preeminent violinists

name: Miles Davis
description: Jazz legend and trumpet virtuoso who revolutionized jazz multiple times throughout his career

name: Louis Armstrong
description: Jazz pioneer and trumpet virtuoso, one of the most influential figures in jazz history

name: Herbie Hancock
description: Jazz piano legend and composer, pioneer in jazz fusion and electronic music

name: Lang Lang
description: International piano superstar known for virtuosic performances and passionate style

name: John Coltrane
description: Jazz saxophone legend and composer, influential in bebop and free jazz

name: Charlie Parker
description: Bebop pioneer and alto saxophone virtuoso, one of the most influential jazz musicians

name: James Galway
description: Renowned flutist known as 'the man with the golden flute', former principal flute of Berlin Philharmonic

name: Jean-Pierre Rampal
description: Legendary flutist who brought the flute to prominence as a solo concert instrument

name: Buddy Rich
description: Legendary jazz drummer known as one of the greatest drummers in history

name: Neil Peart
description: Rush drummer and lyricist, known for complex compositions and technical mastery

name: Dave Grohl
description: Nirvana drummer and Foo Fighters frontman, multi-instrumentalist proficient on drums, guitar, piano, and bass

name: Benny Goodman
description: The 'King of Swing', legendary jazz clarinetist and bandleader

name: Artie Shaw
description: Swing era clarinetist, bandleader, and composer known for innovative arrangements

name: Jaco Pastorius
description: Revolutionary electric bass virtuoso who transformed the instrument's role in jazz and fusion

name: Victor Wooten
description: Five-time Grammy-winning bassist known for innovative techniques and musicality

name: Joanna Newsom
description: Singer-songwriter and harpist known for complex compositions and distinctive voice

name: Harpo Marx
description: Comedian and virtuoso harpist, member of the Marx Brothers comedy team

name: Tommy Dorsey
description: Big band leader and trombone virtuoso known as 'The Sentimental Gentleman of Swing'

name: J.J. Johnson
description: Jazz trombone pioneer who revolutionized bebop trombone playing

name: Béla Fleck
description: Virtuoso banjo player who has taken the instrument far beyond bluegrass into jazz and classical

name: Earl Scruggs
description: Bluegrass legend who developed the three-finger banjo picking style that bears his name

name: Heinz Holliger
description: World-renowned oboist, composer, and conductor

name: Marcel Tabuteau
description: Legendary oboist who shaped American oboe playing style

name: Lionel Hampton
description: Jazz vibraphonist and bandleader who pioneered the vibraphone in jazz and also played xylophone

name: Red Norvo
description: Jazz musician who pioneered the xylophone and vibraphone in jazz

name: Astor Piazzolla
description: Revolutionary tango composer and bandoneón virtuoso who created nuevo tango, also played accordion

name: Yvette Horner
description: French accordionist who popularized musette music

name: Dennis Brain
description: Legendary French horn virtuoso considered the greatest horn player of the 20th century

name: Philip Farkas
description: Renowned French horn player and influential teacher

name: Jake Shimabukuro
description: Ukulele virtuoso who has taken the instrument to new heights with complex arrangements and techniques

name: Israel Kamakawiwoʻole
description: Beloved Hawaiian musician whose medley of 'Over the Rainbow/What a Wonderful World' became iconic

name: Keiko Abe
description: Marimba virtuoso who has commissioned over 300 pieces for the instrument

name: Leigh Howard Stevens
description: Marimba virtuoso who developed the Stevens Grip technique

name: Jacob Collier
description: Multi-Grammy winning multi-instrumentalist proficient on vocals, piano, keyboards, bass, drums, guitar and many more instruments

name: Sting
description: The Police bassist and solo artist, multi-instrumentalist playing bass, guitar, piano, and various other instruments

name: Beck
description: Alternative rock multi-instrumentalist who plays guitar, drums, sitar, banjo, and over 12 instruments

name: Sufjan Stevens
description: Indie folk multi-instrumentalist credited with playing 27+ instruments including guitar, banjo, piano, drums, and various wind and brass instruments

name: Trent Reznor
description: Nine Inch Nails founder who plays over 25 instruments including synthesizers, guitar, piano, saxophone, and cello

name: Flea
description: Red Hot Chili Peppers bassist who also plays trumpet and piano, studied jazz trumpet as a child

name: Jack White
description: The White Stripes frontman, multi-instrumentalist proficient on guitar, piano, drums, and various vintage instruments

name: Dolly Parton
description: Country music legend who plays banjo, guitar, piano, autoharp, violin, and saxophone

name: Taj Mahal
description: Blues musician who plays guitar, piano, banjo, harmonica, and many other instruments, incorporating world music elements

name: Sammy Davis Jr.
description: Legendary entertainer who played trumpet, drums, guitar, bass, violin, saxophone, and piano
